definition: to try hard to catch up
to welcome/to meet/to face/to forge ahead (esp. in the face of difficulties)
suffix for nouns
head/hair style/the top/end/beginning or end/a stub/remnant/chief/boss/side/aspect/first/leading/classifier for pigs or livestock/CL:個|个[ge4]
to overtake/to catch up with/to hurry/to rush/to try to catch (the bus etc)/to drive (cattle etc) forward/to drive (sb) away/to avail oneself of (an opportunity)/until
on top/upon/above/upper/previous/first (of multiple parts)/to climb/to get onto/to go up/to attend (class or university)
see 上聲|上声[shang3 sheng1]

sentences.english: Although the gendarmerie is ahead of the market the market is catching up.
sentences.chinese: 虽然宪兵，是市场上的领先地位，市场正在迎头赶上。

sentences.english: Skyfire fires up fast and web pages load quickly.
sentences.chinese: 天火大火迎头赶上和网页加载迅速。

sentences.english: The science has caught up and the shamans are exposed.
sentences.chinese: 科学已经迎头赶上，巫师的丑恶嘴脸终被曝光。

sentences.english: Europe is extraordinarily chic in Beijing nowadays; the city is making up for lost time.
sentences.chinese: 欧洲人在北京现在很时尚，北京城正在努力迎头赶上。

sentences.english: Spain and France remain the biggest markets, but China is catching up.
sentences.chinese: 西班牙和法国仍是最大市场，但中国正迎头赶上。

sentences.english: Not only had they not kept up, they'd fallen behind.
sentences.chinese: 他们不仅没有迎头赶上，反而是掉队了。

sentences.english: Not only had they not kept up, they’d fallen behind.
sentences.chinese: 他们不仅没有迎头赶上，反而是掉队了。

sentences.english: I wanted the students to have time to catch up.
sentences.chinese: 我希望给予学生迎头赶上的时间。

definition: to overtake
to catch up vigorously/to set off in hot pursuit
lit. late-comer lives above (idiom); the up-and-coming youngster outstrips the older generation/the pupil surpasses the master
lead(ing) position
stuck and not moving forward (idiom); stagnant/in a rut/at a standstill
progress/improvement/to improve/to progress/CL:個|个[ge4]
to pursue/to chase after/to accelerate/to catch up with/to overtake
to overtake on a bend (driving)/(fig.) taking opportunity of tight corners to make swift progress (economy etc)
to run neck and neck/to keep pace with/to keep abreast of/on a par with one another
a long way in front/to lead by a wide margin
to compare a product with (a rival product)/to benchmark against (another product)
to fall behind/to lag (in technology etc)/backward/to retrogress
to rise abruptly (to a towering position)/to tower over/to spring up/to emerge suddenly/the emergence (e.g. of a power)
bellwether

to come first in triennial palace examinations (idiom, refers to the carved stone turtle head in front of the imperial palace, next to which the most successful candidate in the imperial examinations was entitled to stand)/to be the champion/to be the very best in any field
to stand firmly/to gain a foothold/to establish oneself
